Unnamed? Well no need but I'm here. And as much as I hate to say it this congressman is right. The plight of the health care system is costing the lives of 44000 Americans every year...

 
 Another reason people have found it offensive, IMO, is that he used the term 'holocaust', which anyone knows nowadays conjures up thoughts of the Nazi holocaust. 
 That sort of approach gets into matter-of-opinion territory. Example: in the same vein, one could say that it's a "holocaust" that a lot of people have died because they can't defend themselves as well due to laws that they can't carry guns. IOW, ANYONE could claim their issue is a "holocaust" issue with the sort of approach this congressman took. It was a gross over-simplication of rhetoric. 
 
 There are many actions the govt. could take that would conceivably save many lives, and consequently prevent so-called "holocausts". 
 - No doubt we could save lives by making every vaccine we can think of mandatory. But does that mean we should infringe on rights and freedom to force people to do that? 
 - We could save lives in vehicle accidents by making it illegal to drive motor vehicles.
 But this is a free country, and consequently the answer isn't always for the govt. to take part in a govt. controlled program or solution.
foundit66

Another reason people have found it offensive, IMO, is that he used the term 'holocaust', which anyone knows nowadays conjures up thoughts of the Nazi holocaust. 

 I agree. That association is obvious and offensive.
 If only the Republicans who are speaking out against this now could have bothered to comment about their FELLOW REPUBLICANS who make similar allegations regarding Obama and Nazis.
 For one example, alleging that Obama's healthcare plan is similar to tactics employed by the Nazis...
 
 Like this:
 Limbaugh compares Obama's new healthcare logo to Nazi swastika | Top of the Ticket | Los Angeles Times
 Or this:
 http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/05/15/bush-compares-obama-to-na_n_101859.html
 
 
 
There are many actions the govt. could take that would conceivably save many lives, and consequently prevent so-called "holocausts".

 Considering how the United States is one obvious exception in providing top notch healthcare across the board to all citizens, I am curious as to what significant examples you could raise...
 
 
 
- No doubt we could save lives by making every vaccine we can think of mandatory. But does that mean we should infringe on rights and freedom to force people to do that? 

 A poor analogy.
 With the healthcare public option, the obvious intent (as Obama has reiterated himself) is to allow people the CHOICE.
 Currently, people DO NOT have a freedom to choose healthcare that is out of their financial reach!
 
 
 
- We could save lives in vehicle accidents by making it illegal to drive motor vehicles.

 Are you actually comparing giving people MORE CHOICES in healthcare options...
 ... with REMOVING a freedom like driving???
 
 You're actually making that comparison... emoticon_ic
 Wow!
 
 
 
But this is a free country, and consequently the answer isn't always for the govt. to take part in a govt. controlled program or solution.

 I knew that when you started giving examples, you were going to lose sight of the bigger picture.
 Giving people a "public option" IS NOT ABOUT removing a freedom.
 
 And secondly, you say "the answer isn't always"...
 I would be fascinated to hear you explain EXACTLY WHAT type of other feasible answer exists...
 Especially considering approximately 75% of this nation SUPPORT a public option...
 ... and also considering a MAJORITY OF REPUBLICANS SUPPORT a public option, it would seem rather obvious that the REAL solution is to go with giving people a public option.
 
 But if you think you have a counter "answer", then please give it.
 Republicans have been typically silent on actually GIVING answers.
 So I can't help but suspect that your comment was a pointless tautology, implicating that we shouldn't look at THIS answer while you propose ABSOLUTELY NO ALTERNATIVE answer to counter what's on the table..
jyoshu

I agree. That association is obvious and offensive.
 If only the Republicans who are speaking out against this now could have bothered to comment about their FELLOW REPUBLICANS who make similar allegations regarding Obama and Nazis.
 For one example, alleging that Obama's healthcare plan is similar to tactics employed by the Nazis...
 
 Like this:
 Limbaugh compares Obama's new healthcare logo to Nazi swastika | Top of the Ticket | Los Angeles Times
 Or this:
 Bush Compares Obama To Nazi Appeasers

 
 There is a HUGE difference between what this congressman did and the examples you cited.
 
 - Both of your examples were comparisons to Hitler, the first indirect, and the second more direct, whom people also use to exemplify cult-of-personality cases. Frankly, the Obama emblem DID look a lot like the Nazi emblem--that's the reality of it. Regardless of how you feel about Limbaugh, the resemblance IS there ....
 
 - The Huffington article cited Bush using Hitler in an historic example to show how sit-down-work-it-out diplomacy doesn't often work with nutcase leaders. he could have just as easily used other examples--the point being that the REASONS the congressman's example was offensive doesn't apply in the example.
 
 - Regarding what the CONGRESSMAN said, it was a clear invoking of the holocaust. THAT'S why it was offensive--the use of 'holocaust' in this political controversy effectively trivialized the ACTUAL holocaust by bringing it up in a debate that isn't even remotely on the same order. 
 It's the same sort of idiocy we've sometimes heard from gay pride proponents who invoke slavery or the plight of African Americans in the slave era by comparing the issues faced by gay people today.
 
 
A poor analogy.
 With the healthcare public option, the obvious intent (as Obama has reiterated himself) is to allow people the CHOICE.
 Currently, people DO NOT have a freedom to choose healthcare that is out of their financial reach!

 
 The problem is two-fold ...
 It is a program that would cost a fortune to carry out,
 There has to be BETTER safeguards in place to ensure the govt. doesn't undercut private industry in the short term, nor slowly become the SOLE provider in the future. 
 It HAS to fit American principles--that of limited govt. and less reliance on government.
 
 How will a public option help people be LESS reliant on government?
 Let me guess ... you won't address that, will you? :)
 
 
Are you actually comparing giving people MORE CHOICES in healthcare options...
 ... with REMOVING a freedom like driving???

 
 emoticon_wow
 
 LOL, yeeeeaaah, the 'choice' of being reliant on the government teat! Do you consider more and more welfare babies to be engaging in more healthcare CHOICE, in the same vein as creating quality opportunities??? Your "choice" is in a menial government-reliant sense.
 That's no choice of real FREEDOM. You wanna give 'em a fish instead of teaching them to fish ...
 
 
I knew that when you started giving examples, you were going to lose sight of the bigger picture.
 Giving people a "public option" IS NOT ABOUT removing a freedom.

 
 No, the net effect is to make more people dependent on government.
 No thanks.
 
 
Especially considering approximately 75% of this nation SUPPORT a public option...
 ... and also considering a MAJORITY OF REPUBLICANS SUPPORT a public option, it would seem rather obvious that the REAL solution is to go with giving people a public option.

 
 It's interesting that you keep bringing up the fact the majority are for a public option.
 If we took the same reasoning over your main issue--the gay marriage issue--you'd lose on gay marriage, based on THAT argument.
 Interesting that on THAT issue, you don't seem to be interested in harping what the majority thinks. But you do when the issue is one where it's something that happens to fit your preferences.
 
 So given that in OTHER issues (like gay marriage) the majority DOESN"T see it your way, I don't think you really WANT that to be too much of a factor in deciding issues, right? emoticon_xangel
simone

President Bush has said repeatedly that he would not insert himself into the presidential race, but that stance changed dramatically today during his trip to Israel. After likening Iran's President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad to Osama bin Laden, Bush compared Barack Obama to Nazi appeasers:
 
 ".... We have heard this foolish delusion before," Bush said in remarks to the Israeli Knesset. "As Nazi tanks crossed into Poland in 1939, an American Senator declared: 'Lord, if only I could have talked to Hitler, all of this might have been avoided.' We have an obligation to call this what it is -- the false comfort of appeasement, which has been repeatedly discredited by history."

 Bush Compares Obama To Nazi Appeasers
 
 Wonderfully said by someone who has personally profited from the business his grandfather did with Hitler:
 
George Bush's grandfather, the late US senator Prescott Bush, was a director and shareholder of companies that profited from their involvement with the financial backers of Nazi Germany.
 
 The Guardian has obtained confirmation from newly discovered files in the US National Archives that a firm of which Prescott Bush was a director was involved with the financial architects of Nazism.
 
 His business dealings, which continued until his company's assets were seized in 1942 under the Trading with the Enemy Act, has led more than 60 years later to a civil action for damages being brought in Germany against the Bush family by two former slave labourers at Auschwitz and to a hum of pre-election controversy.
 
 The evidence has also prompted one former US Nazi war crimes prosecutor to argue that the late senator's action should have been grounds for prosecution for giving aid and comfort to the enemy. 

 How Bush's grandfather helped Hitler's rise to power | World news | The Guardian
 
 Republican hypocrisy!
foundit66

There is a HUGE difference between what this congressman did and the examples you cited.
 
 - Both of your examples were comparisons to Hitler, the first indirect, and the second more direct, whom people also use to exemplify cult-of-personality cases. Frankly, the Obama emblem DID look a lot like the Nazi emblem--that's the reality of it. Regardless of how you feel about Limbaugh, the resemblance IS there ....

 ROFLMAO!
 So your defense of this indefensible action is to try to VALIDATE the claim...
 emoticon_xdonno
 
 Wow dude.
 I didn't need you to PROVE MY POINT for me...
 
 
 
- The Huffington article cited Bush using Hitler in an historic example to show how sit-down-work-it-out diplomacy doesn't often work with nutcase leaders. he could have just as easily used other examples--the point being that the REASONS the congressman's example was offensive doesn't apply in the example.

 Say WHAT???
 "He could have just as easily used other examples"???
 And THAT is why you think this is different???
 
 Well, golly gee whiz.
 The Democrat in the original article ALSO "could have just as easily used other examples"...
 :xbanghead
 
 So I guess the situations aren't THAT different after all, huh... emoticon_frazzled
 
 
 
- Regarding what the CONGRESSMAN said, it was a clear invoking of the holocaust. THAT'S why it was offensive--the use of 'holocaust' in this political controversy effectively trivialized the ACTUAL holocaust by bringing it up in a debate that isn't even remotely on the same order.

 OMG!
 And the attempts to compare Obama to Hitler SHOULD ALSO be seen as trivializing Hitler.
 Obama is not a man bent on world-wide domination with an Aryan race, stomping Jews under his boot-heel.
 
 Your reply is repugnant in that is actually attempts APOLOGETICS for the problem, instead of just plain BEING HONEST and admitting that the problem is there on both sides and it is INEXCUSABLE (without you providing excuses) for either side...
 
 
 
It's the same sort of idiocy we've sometimes heard from gay pride proponents who invoke slavery or the plight of African Americans in the slave era by comparing the issues faced by gay people today.

 No. The "idiocy" is yours in that it is NOT "slavery" that gay rights proponents typically invoke.
 
 People point to how the state should be able to restrict marriages?
 Gays point to miscegenation laws as an example.
 
 YOU see an issue whereby you mistakenly try to pretend that slavery is somehow poignant to the injustice.
 It isn't.
 Gays don't have to go through slavery in order to get justice.
 
 
 
The problem is two-fold ...

 ROFLMAO!
 And you are about to COMPLETELY IGNORE that your previous analogy was junk, by offering a more direct attack on Obama's healthcare...
 
 And in THIS attack, it isn't an analogy.
 So I'm not going to entertain your attempts to change the subject.
 
 Your previous analogy failed.
 I recognized that it was just a lame attempt to change the subject, and now you try even harder without pretense.
 Pathetic!
 
 
 
LOL, yeeeeaaah, the 'choice' of being reliant on the government teat!

 As opposed to being "reliant on the private insurance teat".
 Do you ever recognize that your replies may play well to the Republican bobble-heads, but these pithy sayings are not really arguments?
 
 
 
Do you consider more and more welfare babies to be engaging in more healthcare CHOICE, in the same vein as creating quality opportunities???

 Can you offer any evidence that a public option will result in more welfare babies?
 
 You're just tossing out wild accusations at this stage...
 
 
 
Your "choice" is in a menial government-reliant sense.
 That's no choice of real FREEDOM. You wanna give 'em a fish instead of teaching them to fish ...

 People like you make me want to vomit.
 You throw out pithy phrases, and refuse to recognize that you're talking about things that YOU DO NOT EVEN ADHERE TO.
 
 You talk about "teaching them to fish".
 Fine.
 SHOW ME HOW you supposedly "teach them to fish"...
 
 The Republican plan is MORE ACCURATELY to block and obfuscate, and inevitably DO NOTHING to change the status quo.
 
 If you have a better alternative to "teach them to fish", then EXPLAIN it.
 
 But the truth is that you just got lost in pithy sayings, and you lacked the self-awareness to recognize that you're putting out excuses and alternatives that DO NOT APPLY to your own position...
 
 
 
It's interesting that you keep bringing up the fact the majority are for a public option.
 If we took the same reasoning over your main issue--the gay marriage issue--you'd lose on gay marriage, based on THAT argument.

 My gawd you are short-sighted.
 How many times do I have to explain this to you before you GET IT???
 
 Gay marriage is a CONSTITUTIONAL issue.
 The reason preventing gay marriage should not be allowed is because it is a CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHT.
 
 There is no constitutional mandate preventing the public option.
 
 For a MORE REAL analogy, take hate crime legislation.
 There is NO constitutional mandate for or against hate crime legislation.
 If the majority actually were AGAINST hate crime legislation, then hate crime legislation SHOULD NOT be enacted.
 See???
 
 
 And Jyoshu, I realize your self-awareness is pathetically low, but do you EVER STOP TO THINK about how your argument swords CUT BOTH WAYS???
 YOU want gay marriage to be prevented because of MAJORITY wishes, right???
 So by YOUR OWN POSITION, endorsing the majority, you should OBVIOUSLY WANT the government to enact a public option as utilization of the democratic standard.
 
 You PERSONALLY are against it, but you should WANT the government to go ahead and follow the majority.
 Is that what you want?
 Or is your observation really just a double-edged sword, pointing out YOUR OWN HYPOCRISY ONCE AGAIN... emoticon_ic
